payload.description: Develop Desktop, Embedded, Mobile and WebAssembly apps with C# and XAML. The most popular .NET Foundation community project.

issue.title: Image scaling problems
issue.body:
## Describe the bug
I'm trying to create an image viewer where the user can use the mouse scroll wheel to zoom in and out.
I am trying two different ways, but have problems with both. 

First way: I am using LayoutTransformControl and in its .LayoutTransform I place a ScaleTransform. In code-behind I manipulate the ScaleX and ScaleY properties of the ScaleTransform.

When I do this, if the image is shrunk down to a size smaller than the control's size, the image is pushed down and to the right, so much that the bottom and/or right of the image cannot be seen because they are outside of the control's bounds, With more scaling, the image is eventually completely push out of view

Second way: I am using the Image control's RenderTransform, setting a ScaleTransform inside that and setting its ScaleX and ScaleY properties.

When the original source image size is small, smaller than the size of the Image Control. I can scale it fine, no issue. But if the source image is large, then scaling down will results in the edges of the image being cropped off (all left, top, right and bottom).


## To Reproduce
I have removed all the code-behind scaling and reproduced the issue directly in the designer (Visual Studio). I have two images, side-by-side in a Grid.

```xaml
<UserControl xmlns="https://github.com/avaloniaui"
             xmlns:x="http://schemas.microsoft.com/winfx/2006/xaml"
             xmlns:d="http://schemas.microsoft.com/expression/blend/2008"
             xmlns:mc="http://schemas.openxmlformats.org/markup-compatibility/2006"
             xmlns:vm="clr-namespace:AvaloniaImageTestBed.ViewModels"
             mc:Ignorable="d" d:DesignWidth="800" d:DesignHeight="450"
             x:Class="AvaloniaImageTestBed.Views.MainView"
             x:DataType="vm:MainViewModel">
  <Design.DataContext>
    <vm:MainViewModel />
  </Design.DataContext>

	<Grid ColumnDefinitions="120, 1*, 1*" RowDefinitions="*" >
		<StackPanel Grid.Row="0" Grid.Column="0" Margin="5">
			<Button HorizontalAlignment="Stretch" HorizontalContentAlignment="Center" Click="LoadImageButton_Click">Load Image</Button>
		</StackPanel>
		
		<Border  BorderBrush="#222" BorderThickness="1"  Padding="4" Grid.Row="0" Grid.Column="1" Margin="5" >
			<ScrollViewer
				x:Name="LeftScrollViewer"
				HorizontalScrollBarVisibility="Hidden"
				VerticalScrollBarVisibility="Hidden"
				PointerMoved="EitherImage_MouseMove"
				Background="Gray"
				Cursor="SizeAll">
				<LayoutTransformControl x:Name="LeftImageTransformControl">
					<LayoutTransformControl.LayoutTransform >
						<ScaleTransform ScaleX="0.45" ScaleY="0.45" />
					</LayoutTransformControl.LayoutTransform>
					<Image
						Name="LeftImage"
						Source="C:\OCR Source Images\eurotext.png"
						Stretch="None"
						PointerWheelChanged="EitherImage_MouseWheel"
					/>
					<!--Source="{Binding LeftBitmap}"-->
				</LayoutTransformControl>

			</ScrollViewer>
		</Border>
		<Border BorderBrush="#222" BorderThickness="1"  Padding="4" Grid.Row="0" Grid.Column="2" Margin="5">
			<Image
				Name="RightImage"
				Source="C:\OCR Source Images\eurotext.png"
				Stretch="None"
				PointerWheelChanged="EitherImage_MouseWheel"
			>
				<Image.RenderTransform>
					<ScaleTransform ScaleX="0.45" ScaleY="0.45" />
				</Image.RenderTransform>
			</Image>
		</Border>
	</Grid>
	
</UserControl>
```



## Expected behavior
For the LayoutTransformControl, when the image is large, the scaling appears to be relative to the top left corner, but as soon as the saling makes the image width or height smaller than the LayoutTransformControl it appear to scale relative to some point far to the bottom right of the LayoutTransformControl.


## Screenshots
Small image, with Scale = 1.0. :
![image](https://github.com/AvaloniaUI/Avalonia/assets/37615629/87623517-fbac-4bfe-8e6d-1f9324e41764)

Small image with scale = 0.5. Shows LayoutTransformControl scaling towards the bottom-right, not the top left, but still all visible. Right image with the RenderTransform looks good.
![image](https://github.com/AvaloniaUI/Avalonia/assets/37615629/f6b81a18-9f70-45f5-ac44-ceee682e32fb)

larger image, with scale = 0.5.  Again shows, in the left image, the LayoutTransformControl scaling towards the bottom-right. Shows in the right image that the scaling crops the image.
![image](https://github.com/AvaloniaUI/Avalonia/assets/37615629/db6dfb4c-71be-439a-bd9c-be41fe451593)

Larg image with , ScaleX="0.3" ScaleY="0.4". Scaling the image to a rectangular shape (not square) or using a rectangular source image, we see that the scaling pushes the image out of the viewport. Playing around with different ScaleX and ScaleY values gets varying results. if they are the same (result is square) sometimes it seems to work - scalled from the top-left with no gray background visible.

![image](https://github.com/AvaloniaUI/Avalonia/assets/37615629/676619d3-935c-4fff-91ce-521ba31c150b)


## Environment 

- OS:  Windows
- IDE: Visual Studio Community 2022
- Avalonia-Version: 11.0.2

comment.body: there should be an option to set Transform Origin. Have you checked it via dev tools (F12) ?

I find the _focusRoot concept a bit confusing. Wouldn't it be better to just stick to focus scopes like in the old implementation?

At least in theory there could be another focus scope between the cleared scope and the VisualRoot.

pull_request.title: Fix some issues with focus scopes
pull_request.body:
## What does the pull request do?

As part of the fix for #13325 I needed to do some basic refactoring to `FocusManager` to fix our broken 2015-era focus scope handling.

- Correctly focus outermost focus scope when a control was removed (previously didn't have enough context to do so, and so this feature only worked when hiding/disabling a control)
- Correctly clear the focused element in a scope when it is removed
- Store the focused element in an attached property instead of a dictionary like WPF: means we need to do a little less bookkeeping

`FocusManager` really needs a rewrite like the one started in #8392 - this PR however doesn't even attempt that, it just aims to fix the existing focus scope handling.

## Fixed issues

Fixes #13325

issue.title: Image scaling problems
issue.body:
## Describe the bug
I'm trying to create an image viewer where the user can use the mouse scroll wheel to zoom in and out.
I am trying two different ways, but have problems with both. 

First way: I am using LayoutTransformControl and in its .LayoutTransform I place a ScaleTransform. In code-behind I manipulate the ScaleX and ScaleY properties of the ScaleTransform.

When I do this, if the image is shrunk down to a size smaller than the control's size, the image is pushed down and to the right, so much that the bottom and/or right of the image cannot be seen because they are outside of the control's bounds, With more scaling, the image is eventually completely push out of view

Second way: I am using the Image control's RenderTransform, setting a ScaleTransform inside that and setting its ScaleX and ScaleY properties.

When the original source image size is small, smaller than the size of the Image Control. I can scale it fine, no issue. But if the source image is large, then scaling down will results in the edges of the image being cropped off (all left, top, right and bottom).


## To Reproduce
I have removed all the code-behind scaling and reproduced the issue directly in the designer (Visual Studio). I have two images, side-by-side in a Grid.

```xaml
<UserControl xmlns="https://github.com/avaloniaui"
             xmlns:x="http://schemas.microsoft.com/winfx/2006/xaml"
             xmlns:d="http://schemas.microsoft.com/expression/blend/2008"
             xmlns:mc="http://schemas.openxmlformats.org/markup-compatibility/2006"
             xmlns:vm="clr-namespace:AvaloniaImageTestBed.ViewModels"
             mc:Ignorable="d" d:DesignWidth="800" d:DesignHeight="450"
             x:Class="AvaloniaImageTestBed.Views.MainView"
             x:DataType="vm:MainViewModel">
  <Design.DataContext>
    <vm:MainViewModel />
  </Design.DataContext>

	<Grid ColumnDefinitions="120, 1*, 1*" RowDefinitions="*" >
		<StackPanel Grid.Row="0" Grid.Column="0" Margin="5">
			<Button HorizontalAlignment="Stretch" HorizontalContentAlignment="Center" Click="LoadImageButton_Click">Load Image</Button>
		</StackPanel>
		
		<Border  BorderBrush="#222" BorderThickness="1"  Padding="4" Grid.Row="0" Grid.Column="1" Margin="5" >
			<ScrollViewer
				x:Name="LeftScrollViewer"
				HorizontalScrollBarVisibility="Hidden"
				VerticalScrollBarVisibility="Hidden"
				PointerMoved="EitherImage_MouseMove"
				Background="Gray"
				Cursor="SizeAll">
				<LayoutTransformControl x:Name="LeftImageTransformControl">
					<LayoutTransformControl.LayoutTransform >
						<ScaleTransform ScaleX="0.45" ScaleY="0.45" />
					</LayoutTransformControl.LayoutTransform>
					<Image
						Name="LeftImage"
						Source="C:\OCR Source Images\eurotext.png"
						Stretch="None"
						PointerWheelChanged="EitherImage_MouseWheel"
					/>
					<!--Source="{Binding LeftBitmap}"-->
				</LayoutTransformControl>

			</ScrollViewer>
		</Border>
		<Border BorderBrush="#222" BorderThickness="1"  Padding="4" Grid.Row="0" Grid.Column="2" Margin="5">
			<Image
				Name="RightImage"
				Source="C:\OCR Source Images\eurotext.png"
				Stretch="None"
				PointerWheelChanged="EitherImage_MouseWheel"
			>
				<Image.RenderTransform>
					<ScaleTransform ScaleX="0.45" ScaleY="0.45" />
				</Image.RenderTransform>
			</Image>
		</Border>
	</Grid>
	
</UserControl>
```



## Expected behavior
For the LayoutTransformControl, when the image is large, the scaling appears to be relative to the top left corner, but as soon as the saling makes the image width or height smaller than the LayoutTransformControl it appear to scale relative to some point far to the bottom right of the LayoutTransformControl.


## Screenshots
Small image, with Scale = 1.0. :
![image](https://github.com/AvaloniaUI/Avalonia/assets/37615629/87623517-fbac-4bfe-8e6d-1f9324e41764)

Small image with scale = 0.5. Shows LayoutTransformControl scaling towards the bottom-right, not the top left, but still all visible. Right image with the RenderTransform looks good.
![image](https://github.com/AvaloniaUI/Avalonia/assets/37615629/f6b81a18-9f70-45f5-ac44-ceee682e32fb)

larger image, with scale = 0.5.  Again shows, in the left image, the LayoutTransformControl scaling towards the bottom-right. Shows in the right image that the scaling crops the image.
![image](https://github.com/AvaloniaUI/Avalonia/assets/37615629/db6dfb4c-71be-439a-bd9c-be41fe451593)

Larg image with , ScaleX="0.3" ScaleY="0.4". Scaling the image to a rectangular shape (not square) or using a rectangular source image, we see that the scaling pushes the image out of the viewport. Playing around with different ScaleX and ScaleY values gets varying results. if they are the same (result is square) sometimes it seems to work - scalled from the top-left with no gray background visible.

![image](https://github.com/AvaloniaUI/Avalonia/assets/37615629/676619d3-935c-4fff-91ce-521ba31c150b)


## Environment 

- OS:  Windows
- IDE: Visual Studio Community 2022
- Avalonia-Version: 11.0.2

comment.body:
Thanks @timunie . I've just tried 11.0.5 and nightly build 11.0.999 and I get the same behavior. 

P.s. forget what I said about square vs rectangular image. It's actually related to the scaled image's width or height being any larger than the parent control's width or height.

@Gillibald this fixes what I think was an incorrect change in [one of your commits](https://github.com/AvaloniaUI/Avalonia/commit/6210018f3b5e98063252d2bf2933e1739ed17f85#diff-b9c372514271a3da80207200fb37c0f5e9ef566ec7bff8db21f9190c6a1540cbR80). I think the change in that commit was wrong because `VisualParent` should always be `null` for `PopupRoot` considering that it's a visual root.

pull_request.title: Fix some issues with focus scopes
pull_request.body:
## What does the pull request do?

As part of the fix for #13325 I needed to do some basic refactoring to `FocusManager` to fix our broken 2015-era focus scope handling.

- Correctly focus outermost focus scope when a control was removed (previously didn't have enough context to do so, and so this feature only worked when hiding/disabling a control)
- Correctly clear the focused element in a scope when it is removed
- Store the focused element in an attached property instead of a dictionary like WPF: means we need to do a little less bookkeeping

`FocusManager` really needs a rewrite like the one started in #8392 - this PR however doesn't even attempt that, it just aims to fix the existing focus scope handling.

## Fixed issues

Fixes #13325

commits.message: Added failing focus scope tests.

Refactor focus scopes in FocusManager.

- Store focused element within a scope using an attached property (like WPF)
- Store current focus root so that focus can be restored to that root when a focused control or active focus scope is removed

Fixes #13325

issue.title: Image scaling problems
issue.body:
## Describe the bug
I'm trying to create an image viewer where the user can use the mouse scroll wheel to zoom in and out.
I am trying two different ways, but have problems with both. 

First way: I am using LayoutTransformControl and in its .LayoutTransform I place a ScaleTransform. In code-behind I manipulate the ScaleX and ScaleY properties of the ScaleTransform.

When I do this, if the image is shrunk down to a size smaller than the control's size, the image is pushed down and to the right, so much that the bottom and/or right of the image cannot be seen because they are outside of the control's bounds, With more scaling, the image is eventually completely push out of view

Second way: I am using the Image control's RenderTransform, setting a ScaleTransform inside that and setting its ScaleX and ScaleY properties.

When the original source image size is small, smaller than the size of the Image Control. I can scale it fine, no issue. But if the source image is large, then scaling down will results in the edges of the image being cropped off (all left, top, right and bottom).


## To Reproduce
I have removed all the code-behind scaling and reproduced the issue directly in the designer (Visual Studio). I have two images, side-by-side in a Grid.

```xaml
<UserControl xmlns="https://github.com/avaloniaui"
             xmlns:x="http://schemas.microsoft.com/winfx/2006/xaml"
             xmlns:d="http://schemas.microsoft.com/expression/blend/2008"
             xmlns:mc="http://schemas.openxmlformats.org/markup-compatibility/2006"

		<StackPanel Grid.Row="0" Grid.Column="0" Margin="5">
			<Button HorizontalAlignment="Stretch" HorizontalContentAlignment="Center" Click="LoadImageButton_Click">Load Image</Button>

		<Border  BorderBrush="#222" BorderThickness="1"  Padding="4" Grid.Row="0" Grid.Column="1" Margin="5" >

						<ScaleTransform ScaleX="0.45" ScaleY="0.45" />

						Name="LeftImage"
						Source="C:\OCR Source Images\eurotext.png"
						Stretch="None"
						PointerWheelChanged="EitherImage_MouseWheel"
					/>
					<!--Source="{Binding LeftBitmap}"-->
				</LayoutTransformControl>

			</ScrollViewer>
		</Border>
		<Border BorderBrush="#222" BorderThickness="1"  Padding="4" Grid.Row="0" Grid.Column="2" Margin="5">
			<Image
				Name="RightImage"
				Source="C:\OCR Source Images\eurotext.png"
				Stretch="None"
				PointerWheelChanged="EitherImage_MouseWheel"
			>
				<Image.RenderTransform>
					<ScaleTransform ScaleX="0.45" ScaleY="0.45" />
				</Image.RenderTransform>
			</Image>
		</Border>
	</Grid>
	
</UserControl>
```



## Expected behavior
For the LayoutTransformControl, when the image is large, the scaling appears to be relative to the top left corner, but as soon as the saling makes the image width or height smaller than the LayoutTransformControl it appear to scale relative to some point far to the bottom right of the LayoutTransformControl.


## Screenshots
Small image, with Scale = 1.0. :
![image](https://github.com/AvaloniaUI/Avalonia/assets/37615629/87623517-fbac-4bfe-8e6d-1f9324e41764)

Small image with scale = 0.5. Shows LayoutTransformControl scaling towards the bottom-right, not the top left, but still all visible. Right image with the RenderTransform looks good.

larger image, with scale = 0.5.  Again shows, in the left image, the LayoutTransformControl scaling towards the bottom-right. Shows in the right image that the scaling crops the image.

Playing around with different ScaleX and ScaleY values gets varying results. if they are the same (result is square) sometimes it seems to work - scalled from the top-left with no gray background visible.

comment.body: please check issues against latest stable (11.0.5) or event better nightly. Can you double-check if it is still reproduced in latest versions?

issue.title: Implement Text Selection handles in TextBox for touch input
issue.body:
<!--- See CONTRIBUTING.md for general guidelines on contributions -->

## What does the pull request do?
Implements text selection handles in textbox that allow changing text selection by dragging. This is activated by non-mouse input, i.e. touch and pen. This provides similar text selection behavior to what users are familiar with on android and iOS.

https://github.com/AvaloniaUI/Avalonia/assets/5307160/53da0119-eb36-4294-975f-59b9fef7e308

In addition, the textbox context menu has been simplified and optimized for mobile.

https://github.com/AvaloniaUI/Avalonia/assets/5307160/21f44470-e8dc-44de-99a0-0c2922b80c2c

Though what I've planned for this pr is all in, it's still subject to change, so comments on implementation details and recommendations are welcome.

## What is the current behavior?
Currently, text can only be be selected by dragging the caret along the text. This makes it very inaccurate on touch devices, and text selection is easily reset by accidental touches.


## What is the updated/expected behavior with this PR?
<!--- Describe how to test the PR. -->


## How was the solution implemented (if it's not obvious)?
SelectionHandles must be drawn over all other controls, and though visibility of the handles is affected by the current text cursor, it shouldn't be clipped. As such, a new visual layer with a higher z-index is used to host the handles. This has the side effect of selection handles drawing over hosted popups, which are drawn in the OverlayLayer. It's possible to add text controls to the OverlayLayer, as such, that layer is not suitable to host selection handles.


## Checklist

- [ ] Added unit tests (if possible)?
- [ ] Added XML documentation to any related classes?
- [ ] Consider submitting a PR to https://github.com/AvaloniaUI/avalonia-docs with user documentation

## Breaking changes
This is a behavioral breaking change.

## Obsoletions / Deprecations
<!--- Obsolete and Deprecated attributes on APIs MUST only be included when discussed with Core team. @grokys, @kekekeks & @danwalmsley -->

## Fixed issues
<!--- If the pull request fixes issue(s) list them like this: 
Fixes #123
Fixes #456
-->

comment.body: @MrJul Should be good now. could you try again?

commits.message:
Fix TextLayout.OverhandLeading calculation (#13287)

* Fix overhand leading calculation

* Fix test on Mac

* Fix tests

Add tooltip support to NativeMenuItem. (#13350)

* Add tooltip support to NativeMenuItem.

* Add support for NativeMenuItem tooltips on macOS.
Update HarfBuzzSharp (#13357)

Add TextBox.ScrollToLine (#13274)

* Add TextBox.ScrollToLine #3036

* Test data in arabic for RTL testing

fix(CaptionButton): theme used hardcoded Background, Foreground and BorderBrush color (#13373)

* fix(CaptionButtons): FluentCaptionButton theme used hardcoded Background, Foreground and BorderBrush color

* fix(CaptionButtons): SimpleCaptionButton theme used hardcoded Background, Foreground and BorderBrush color

Implement DirectComposition support, as well as return Win8+ window transparency (#13382)

* Init DirectComposition support

* Use Win8.1 as a minimum dcomp target, avoid hacks with render timer

* Refactor transparency supprot a little

* Cleanups

* Restore old hack as I don't know how to remove it yet
Fix ShapedTextRun Split for sequences that contain invisible character that belong to the same cluster (#13385)

Fix SystemFontCollection nearest match lookup (#13365)

* Try to find nearest matching glyphTypeface when no exact match could by found by SystemFontCollection

* Fix glyphTypeface caching

* Rework SystemFontCollection TryCreateGlyphTypeface

* Make sure a failed glyphTypeface lookup is cached

* Make sure to only try to get nearest match if we failed to load the font via font magager impl

* Apply font simulations if possible

* Enable font simulation for embedded fonts

* Adjust simulated angle
Fix previewing XAML in the Simple theme project (#13394)

Add method to cancel currently ongoing gesture on a pointer (#13351)

* add method to cancel currently ongoing gesture on a pointer

* skip gesture recognition for pointer capture session, revert cancel gesture changes
add text selection handles
only show selectors on pen and touch input
show mobile themed context menu on mobile
cleanup and track textbox layout changes with EffectiveViewportChanged
make SelectionHandleType as clr property
fix custom flyouts not showing with selection handles
simplify text context menu for mobile.
cleanup
address review, simplify styles, add docs
remove unused resource

issue.title: Image scaling problems
issue.body:
## Describe the bug
I'm trying to create an image viewer where the user can use the mouse scroll wheel to zoom in and out.
I am trying two different ways, but have problems with both. 

First way: I am using LayoutTransformControl and in its .LayoutTransform I place a ScaleTransform. In code-behind I manipulate the ScaleX and ScaleY properties of the ScaleTransform.

When I do this, if the image is shrunk down to a size smaller than the control's size, the image is pushed down and to the right, so much that the bottom and/or right of the image cannot be seen because they are outside of the control's bounds, With more scaling, the image is eventually completely push out of view

Second way: I am using the Image control's RenderTransform, setting a ScaleTransform inside that and setting its ScaleX and ScaleY properties.

When the original source image size is small, smaller than the size of the Image Control. I can scale it fine, no issue. But if the source image is large, then scaling down will results in the edges of the image being cropped off (all left, top, right and bottom).


## To Reproduce
I have removed all the code-behind scaling and reproduced the issue directly in the designer (Visual Studio). I have two images, side-by-side in a Grid.

```xaml
<UserControl xmlns="https://github.com/avaloniaui"
             xmlns:x="http://schemas.microsoft.com/winfx/2006/xaml"
             xmlns:d="http://schemas.microsoft.com/expression/blend/2008"
             xmlns:mc="http://schemas.openxmlformats.org/markup-compatibility/2006"
             xmlns:vm="clr-namespace:AvaloniaImageTestBed.ViewModels"
             mc:Ignorable="d" d:DesignWidth="800" d:DesignHeight="450"
             x:Class="AvaloniaImageTestBed.Views.MainView"
             x:DataType="vm:MainViewModel">
  <Design.DataContext>
    <vm:MainViewModel />
  </Design.DataContext>

	<Grid ColumnDefinitions="120, 1*, 1*" RowDefinitions="*" >
		<StackPanel Grid.Row="0" Grid.Column="0" Margin="5">
			<Button HorizontalAlignment="Stretch" HorizontalContentAlignment="Center" Click="LoadImageButton_Click">Load Image</Button>
		</StackPanel>
		
		<Border  BorderBrush="#222" BorderThickness="1"  Padding="4" Grid.Row="0" Grid.Column="1" Margin="5" >
			<ScrollViewer
				x:Name="LeftScrollViewer"
				HorizontalScrollBarVisibility="Hidden"
				VerticalScrollBarVisibility="Hidden"
				PointerMoved="EitherImage_MouseMove"
				Background="Gray"
				Cursor="SizeAll">
				<LayoutTransformControl x:Name="LeftImageTransformControl">
					<LayoutTransformControl.LayoutTransform >
						<ScaleTransform ScaleX="0.45" ScaleY="0.45" />
					</LayoutTransformControl.LayoutTransform>
					<Image
						Name="LeftImage"
						Source="C:\OCR Source Images\eurotext.png"
						Stretch="None"
						PointerWheelChanged="EitherImage_MouseWheel"
					/>
					<!--Source="{Binding LeftBitmap}"-->
				</LayoutTransformControl>

			</ScrollViewer>
		</Border>
		<Border BorderBrush="#222" BorderThickness="1"  Padding="4" Grid.Row="0" Grid.Column="2" Margin="5">
			<Image
				Name="RightImage"
				Source="C:\OCR Source Images\eurotext.png"
				Stretch="None"
				PointerWheelChanged="EitherImage_MouseWheel"
			>
				<Image.RenderTransform>
					<ScaleTransform ScaleX="0.45" ScaleY="0.45" />
				</Image.RenderTransform>
			</Image>
		</Border>
	</Grid>
	
</UserControl>
```



## Expected behavior
For the LayoutTransformControl, when the image is large, the scaling appears to be relative to the top left corner, but as soon as the saling makes the image width or height smaller than the LayoutTransformControl it appear to scale relative to some point far to the bottom right of the LayoutTransformControl.


## Screenshots
Small image, with Scale = 1.0. :
![image](https://github.com/AvaloniaUI/Avalonia/assets/37615629/87623517-fbac-4bfe-8e6d-1f9324e41764)

Small image with scale = 0.5. Shows LayoutTransformControl scaling towards the bottom-right, not the top left, but still all visible. Right image with the RenderTransform looks good.
![image](https://github.com/AvaloniaUI/Avalonia/assets/37615629/f6b81a18-9f70-45f5-ac44-ceee682e32fb)

larger image, with scale = 0.5.  Again shows, in the left image, the LayoutTransformControl scaling towards the bottom-right. Shows in the right image that the scaling crops the image.
![image](https://github.com/AvaloniaUI/Avalonia/assets/37615629/db6dfb4c-71be-439a-bd9c-be41fe451593)

Larg image with , ScaleX="0.3" ScaleY="0.4". Scaling the image to a rectangular shape (not square) or using a rectangular source image, we see that the scaling pushes the image out of the viewport. Playing around with different ScaleX and ScaleY values gets varying results. if they are the same (result is square) sometimes it seems to work - scalled from the top-left with no gray background visible.

![image](https://github.com/AvaloniaUI/Avalonia/assets/37615629/676619d3-935c-4fff-91ce-521ba31c150b)


## Environment 

- OS:  Windows
- IDE: Visual Studio Community 2022
- Avalonia-Version: 11.0.2

issue.title: Assembly signing
issue.body:
In the wake of #5937 and #5938, a lot of users of Avalonia-built applications were seeing Windows Defender block those applications. Windows Defender claimed to have found a Trojan and as a "Severe" classification, deleted the assemblies. This resulted in a number of users being unable to launch the application until they somehow re-downloaded that assembly (usually by reinstalling the application).

The real solution is to sign the Avalonia assemblies.

comment.body:
Cecil is a dependency that processes assemblies during XAML compilation.
Btw, please open a new issue, as yours and [josephnarai](https://github.com/josephnarai) isn't related to authenticode signing discussed in this topic.

issue.title: Assembly signing
issue.body:
In the wake of #5937 and #5938, a lot of users of Avalonia-built applications were seeing Windows Defender block those applications. Windows Defender claimed to have found a Trojan and as a "Severe" classification, deleted the assemblies. This resulted in a number of users being unable to launch the application until they somehow re-downloaded that assembly (usually by reinstalling the application).

The real solution is to sign the Avalonia assemblies.

comment.body:
Who/what is Cecil?

By the way, I pondered the idea of faulty environment but this error is also thrown in Azure Pipelines where I use msbuild.
